evals.prompt: Hey, can you check my progress? I've been working on this feature and want a second pair of eyes.
evals.expected_output: Navigator gathers git context, reads changed files, then provides focused conversational feedback without filler or forced praise
assertions: Runs git commands to gather branch context (git status, git diff, git log or similar)
Reads the full content of modified files, not just the diffs
Identifies both what the user is building and the approach they are taking
Provides feedback in a conversational tone using paragraphs, not numbered lists, bullet points, or bold-header sections
Makes multiple specific observations about the actual code, covering at least two of: architecture/design, correctness/bugs, edge cases, testing
Technical claims in the response are accurate and verifiable against the actual code (no hallucinated details about files, functions, or behavior)
Does not include forced or gratuitous praise — no 'great job', 'nice work', 'well done', 'clean implementation', or similar compliments unless they serve a specific technical point
Does not rewrite or modify any code unless asked
Response is tightly scoped — no more than 3 short paragraphs of feedback text (excluding the initial context-gathering phase), roughly 150-250 words of actual feedback

evals.prompt: What do you think? Am I on the right track?
evals.expected_output: Navigator assesses the current direction and raises concerns conversationally, without padding with compliments
assertions: Gathers context before responding (does not jump straight to opinions)
Assesses the overall approach and direction, not just line-level details
Either asks clarifying questions about ambiguous intent OR demonstrates thorough context gathering sufficient to provide a meaningful assessment
Challenges at least two assumptions or raises multiple potential concerns with reasoning
Response feels like a conversation, not a code review checklist — uses paragraphs and natural transitions between topics
Technical claims are accurate and verifiable against the actual code
Suggestions are actionable — concrete enough for the user to act on without guessing what was meant
Does not pad the response with praise or positive affirmations — gets straight to substantive observations
Response is concise — no more than 3 short paragraphs of feedback, roughly 150-250 words

evals.expected_output: Navigator performs full peer review workflow: gather context, understand changes, provide tight conversational feedback without filler
assertions: Follows the full skill workflow: gathers git context, reads changed files, then provides feedback (not just triggering)
Gathers full branch context including uncommitted changes (git diff), staged changes (git diff --cached), and committed changes (git log, diff against base branch)
Reads changed files in full to understand surrounding code, not just the diffs
Adapts feedback focus to the apparent stage of work — explicitly acknowledges how far along the work is and adjusts what it covers accordingly
Prioritizes substantive feedback (bugs, design, edge cases, testing gaps) over style nits — no formatting or naming suggestions unless egregious
Maintains conversational tone throughout — paragraphs, not lists or headers
Technical observations are accurate and verifiable against the actual code
Does not include obligatory praise or compliments — every sentence should carry substantive information
Response is tightly scoped — no more than 3 short paragraphs of feedback (~150-250 words), with an offer to go deeper if the user wants
